question.text: A bubble has surface tension <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>S</mi></math>. The ideal gas inside the bubble has ratio of specific heats <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>γ</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>. The bubble is exposed to the atmosphere and it always retains its spherical shape. When the atmospheric pressure is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></math>, the radius of the bubble is found to be <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and the temperature of the enclosed gas is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. When the atmospheric pressure is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>, the radius of the bubble and the temperature of the enclosed gas are <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, respectively. Which of the following statement(s) is(are) correct?

options.text: If the surface of the bubble is a perfect heat insulator, then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mfenced><mfrac><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mfrac></mfenced><mn>5</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>S</mi></mrow><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mfrac></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>S</mi></mrow><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></mrow></mfrac></math>
If the surface of the bubble is a perfect heat insulator, then the total internal energy of the bubble including its surface energy does not change with the external atmospheric pressure.

If the surface of the bubble is a perfect heat conductor and the change in atmospheric temperature is negligible, the <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mfenced><mfrac><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mfrac></mfenced><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>S</mi></mrow><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mfrac></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>S</mi></mrow><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></mrow></mfrac></math>

If the surface of the bubble is a perfect heat insulator, then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mfenced><mfrac><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></mfenced><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>S</mi></mrow><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mfrac></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>S</mi></mrow><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></mrow></mfrac></math>

solution.text:
When, 

PressureRadiusTemperaturePa1→r1→T1Pa2→r2→T2

For adiabatic process

P1V1γ=P2V2γ

Pa1+4Tr143πr1353=Pa2+4Tr243πr2353

r1r25=Pa2+4Tr2Pa1+4Tr1

Therefore, option A is incorrect.

Now,

T1V1γ-1=T2V2γ-1

T2T1=V1V2γ-1=r1r2323

T2T1=Pa2+4Tr2Pa1+4Tr125

Therefore, option D is correct.

For option B Total internal energy + surface energy will not be same as work done by gas will be there. Option B is incorrect.

For option C change in temperature is negligible. Therefore, the process is isothermal.

P1V1=P2V2

Pa1+4Tr143πr13=Pa2+4Tr243πr23

r1r23=Pa2+4Tr2Pa1+4Tr1

Option C is correct.
